mfm.fluorescence.anisotropy.calculate_kappa_distance(xyz, aid1, aid2, aia1, aia2)[source]¶

Calculates the orientation factor kappa2 and the distance of a trajectory given the atom-indices of the donor and the acceptor.

Parameters:
  • xyz – numpy-array (frame, atom, xyz)
  • aid1 – int, atom-index of d-dipole 1
  • aid2 – int, atom-index of d-dipole 2
  • aia1 – int, atom-index of a-dipole 1
  • aia2 – int, atom-index of a-dipole 2
Returns:

distances, kappa2

mfm.fluorescence.anisotropy.s2delta(r_0, s2donor, s2acceptor, r_inf_AD)[source]¶

calculate delta given residual anisotropies

Parameters:
  • r_0 –
  • s2donor – -np.sqrt(self.r_Dinf/self.r_0)
  • s2acceptor – np.sqrt(self.r_Ainf/self.r_0)
  • r_inf_DA –

Accurate Distance Determination of Nucleic Acids via Foerster Resonance Energy Transfer: Implications of Dye Linker Length and Rigidity http://pubs.acs.org/doi/full/10.1021/ja105725e

mfm.fluorescence.general module¶

mfm.fluorescence.general.calc_decay_matrix(t, tau_min=0.01, tau_max=200.0, n_steps=200.0, space='lin')[source]¶

Calculates a fluorescence decay matrix converting probabilities of lifetimes to a time-resolved fluorescence intensity

Parameters:
  • t –
  • tau_min –
  • tau_max –
  • n_steps –
  • space –

Examples

>>> t = np.arange(0, 20, 0.0141)
>>> m, r_da = calc_decay_matrix(t)

Now plot the decay matrix

>>> import pylab as p
>>> p.imshow(m)
>>> p.show()
mfm.fluorescence.general.calc_transfer_matrix(t, rDA_min=1.0, rDA_max=200.0, n_steps=200.0, kappa2=0.667, space='lin', **kwargs)[source]¶

Calculates a matrix converting a distance distribution to an E(t)-decay

Parameters:
  • t –
  • rDA_min –
  • rDA_max –
  • n_steps –
  • kappa2 –
  • log_space –
  • kwargs –

    tau0 - lifetime, R0 - Forster-radius, n_donor_bins: int (default 10)

    the number of bins with rate 0.0 (Donor-only). The longest distances are replaced by zero-rates

Examples

>>> t = np.arange(0, 20, 0.0141)
>>> m, r_da = calc_transfer_matrix(t)

(Source code)

mfm.fluorescence.general.calculate_fluorescence_decay[source]¶

Converts a interleaved lifetime spectrum into a intensity decay

Parameters:
  • lifetime_spectrum – interleaved lifetime spectrum
  • time_axis – time-axis
Returns:

Examples

>>> time_axis = np.linspace(0, 20, num=100)
>>> structure = mfm.structure.Structure('./sample_data/modelling/pdb_files/hGBP1_closed.pdb')
>>> donor_description = {'residue_seq_number': 344, 'atom_name': 'CB'}
>>> acceptor_description = {'residue_seq_number': 496, 'atom_name': 'CB'}
>>> donor_lifetime_spectrum = np.array([1., 4.])
>>> lifetime_spectrum = structure.av_lifetime_spectrum(donor_lifetime_spectrum, donor_description, acceptor_description)
>>> time_axis, decay = calculate_fluorescence_decay(lifetime_spectrum, time_axis)

mfm.fluorescence.general.e1tn[source]¶

Multiply amplitudes of rate spectrum by float

Parameters:
  • e1 – array-like Rate spectrum
  • n – float

Examples

>>> e1 = np.array([1,2,3,4])
>>> e1tn(e1, 2.0)
array([2, 2, 6, 4])
mfm.fluorescence.general.elte2[source]¶

Takes two interleaved spectrum of lifetimes (a11, l11, a12, l12,...) and (a21, l21, a22, l22,...) and return a new spectrum of lifetimes of the form (a11*a21, 1/(1/l11+1/l21), a12*a22, 1/(1/l22+1/l22), ...)

Parameters:
  • e1 – array-like Lifetime spectrum 1
  • e2 – array-like Lifetime spectrum 2
Returns:

array-like Lifetime-spectrum

Examples

>>> import numpy as np
>>> e1 = np.array([1,2,3,4])
>>> e2 = np.array([5,6,7,8])
>>> elte2(e1, e2)
array([  5.        ,   1.5       ,   7.        ,   1.6       ,
    15.        ,   2.4       ,  21.        ,   2.66666667])
mfm.fluorescence.general.et(fd0, fda)¶
mfm.fluorescence.general.et2pRDA(ts, et, t_matrix=None, r_DA=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Calculates the distance distribution given an E(t) decay Here the amplitudes of E(t) are passed as well as the time-axis. If no transfer-matrix is provided it will be calculated in a range from 5 Ang to 200 Ang assuming a lifetime of 4 ns with a Forster-radius of 52 Ang. These parameters can be provided by kwargs

Parameters:
  • t –
  • et –
  • t_matrix –
  • r_DA –
  • kwargs – tau0 donor-lifetime in absence of quenching, R0 - Forster-Radius
Returns:

a distance and probability array

Examples

First calculate an E(t)-decay

>>> rda_mean = [45.1, 65.0]
>>> rda_sigma = [8.0, 8.0]
>>> amplitudes = [0.6, 0.4]
>>> rates = gaussian2rates(rda_mean, rda_sigma, amplitudes, interleaved=False)
>>> a = rates[:,0]
>>> kFRET = rates[:,1]
>>> ts = np.logspace(0.1, 3, 18000)
>>> et = np.array([np.dot(a, np.exp(-kFRET * t)) for t in ts])

mfm.fluorescence.general.gaussian2rates(means, sigmas, amplitudes, tau0=4.0, kappa2=0.667, R0=52.0, n_points=64, m_sigma=1.5, interleaved=True)[source]¶

Calculate distribution of FRET-rates given a list of normal/Gaussian distributed distances.

Parameters:
  • means – array
  • sigmas – array
  • amplitudes – array
  • tau0 – float
  • kappa2 – float
  • R0 – float
  • n_points – int
  • m_sigma – float
Returns:

either an interleaved rate-spectrum, or a 2D-array stack

Examples

This generates an interleaved array here it follows the rule: amplitude, rate, amplitude, rate, ...

>>> gaussian2rates([50], [8.0], [1.0], interleaved=True, n_points=8)
array([ 0.06060222,  1.64238732,  0.10514622,  0.97808684,  0.1518205 ,
        0.60699836,  0.18243106,  0.39018018,  0.18243106,  0.25853181,
        0.1518205 ,  0.17589017,  0.10514622,  0.12247918,  0.06060222,
        0.08706168])

If interleaved is False a 2D-numpy array is returned. The first dimension corresponds to the amplitudes the second to the rates.

>>> gaussian2rates([50], [8.0], [1.0], interleaved=False, n_points=8)
array([[ 0.06060222,  1.64238732],
       [ 0.10514622,  0.97808684],
       [ 0.1518205 ,  0.60699836],
       [ 0.18243106,  0.39018018],
       [ 0.18243106,  0.25853181],
       [ 0.1518205 ,  0.17589017],
       [ 0.10514622,  0.12247918],
       [ 0.06060222,  0.08706168]])

mfm.fluorescence.general.stack_lifetime_spectra(lifetime_spectra, fractions, normalize_fractions=True)[source]¶

Takes an array of lifetime spectra and an array of fractions and returns an mixed array of lifetimes whereas the amplitudes are multiplied by the fractions. normalize_fractions is True the fractions are normalized to one.

Returns:numpy-array
mfm.fluorescence.general.transfer2distance[source]¶

Converts the transfer-efficency to a distance

\[R_{DA} = R_0 (1 / E - 1)^{1/6}\]

  • R0 – Forster-radius
